messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On ùê∂‚Å∞-persistent homology and trees

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper we give a metric construction of a tree which correctly identifies connected components of superlevel sets of continuous functions f:X‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üíùëã‚Ñùf:X\to\mathbb{R} and show that it is possible to retrieve the H0subscriptùêª0H_{0}-persistent diagram from this tree. We revisit the notion of homological dimension previously introduced by Schweinhart and give some bounds for the latter in terms of the upper-box dimension of XùëãX, thereby partially answering a question of the same author. We prove a quantitative version of the Wasserstein stability theorem valid for regular enough XùëãX and Œ±ùõº\alpha-H√∂lder functions and discuss some applications of this theory to random fields and the topology of their superlevel sets.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A fractal dimension for measures via persistent homology",
        "Persistence images: A stable vector representation of persistent homology",
        "Persistent homology for random fields and complexes",
        "Random Fields and Geometry",
        "Kolmogorov-Chentsov theorem and differentiability of random fields on manifolds",
        "Some Nonlinear Problems in Riemannian Geometry",
        "Time series, persistent homology and chirality",
        "Homotopy-everything h‚Ñéh-spaces",
        "Homotopy Invariant Algebraic Structures on Topological Spaces",
        "Topological spaces of persistence modules and their properties",
        "A course in metric geometry, volume 33 of Graduate Studies in Mathematics",
        "Sliced Wasserstein Kernel for Persistence Diagrams",
        "The Structure and Stability of Persistence Modules",
        "The density of expected persistence diagrams and its kernel based estimation",
        "Subsampling methods for persistent homology",
        "Convergence rates for persistence diagram estimation in topological data analysis",
        "Diffusion runs low on persistence fast",
        "Introduction to ŒõŒõ\\Lambda-Trees",
        "Unbalanced optimal transport: Dynamic and kantorovich formulation",
        "Lipschitz functions have LpsuperscriptùêøùëùL^{p}-stable persistence",
        "The Brownian cactus I. Scaling limits of discrete cactuses",
        "The fiber of the persistence map for functions on the interval",
        "Decorated merge trees for persistent topology",
        "Understanding the topology and the geometry of the persistence diagram space via optimal partial transport",
        "Estimation and quantization of expected persistence diagrams",
        "On the choice of weight functions for linear representations of persistence diagrams",
        "Random trees, L√©vy processes and spatial branching processes",
        "Probabilistic and fractal aspects of L√©vy trees",
        "Computational Topology: An Introduction",
        "Foundations of Algebraic Topology",
        "Confidence sets for persistence diagrams",
        "The optimal partial transport problem",
        "A new transportation distance between non-negative measures, with applications to gradients flows with dirichlet boundary conditions",
        "Koszul duality for operads",
        "A class of Wasserstein metrics for probability distributions",
        "Manifolds of positive ricci curvature with quadratically asymptotically nonnegative curvature and infinite topological type",
        "Some random series of functions",
        "A new optimal transport distance on the space of finite Radon measures",
        "The minimal spanning tree and the upper box dimension",
        "La renaissance des op√©rades",
        "Measuring shape with topology",
        "The Geometry of Iterated Loop Spaces",
        "Reeb posets and tree approximations",
        "Examples of strictly weakly regular points",
        "Examples of manifolds and spaces with positive Ricci curvature",
        "Probability measures on the space of persistence diagrams",
        "The ‚Ñì‚Ñì\\ell ‚àû\\infty-cophenetic metric for phylogenetic trees as an interleaving distance",
        "Persistence Theory - From Quiver Representations to Data Analysis, volume 209 of Mathematical surveys and monographs",
        "On the persistent homology of almost surely C0superscriptùê∂0C^{0} stochastic processes",
        "A tree approach to pùëùp-variation and to integration",
        "Persistence barcodes and Laplace eigenfunctions on surfaces",
        "Topological Persistence in Geometry and Analysis",
        "Persistent homology and the upper box dimension",
        "Wasserstein stability for persistence diagrams",
        "Enumerative Combinatorics",
        "Fr√©chet means for distributions of persistence diagrams",
        "The JS-graphs of join and split trees",
        "General topology"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On ùê∂‚Å∞-persistent homology and trees, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
